chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Management - chronic complications
chapter.summary: Covers the management of chronic complications of sickle cell disease in primary care.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From birth onwards.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Overview of management
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The management of chronic complications of sickle cell disease needs a multidisciplinary approach. Children and adults are seen regularly in secondary care. However, it is recommended that as much of the management as possible should take place in the community.

  • Primary care clinicians should:
    • Admit or refer people immediately if they have new symptoms of cerebrovascular disease, as acute strokes are devastating in both children and adults.
    • Manage chronic pain with care.
    • Treat chest infections early, especially in people with chronic sickle lung.
    • Refer people with eye problems urgently. 
    • Refer people for consideration for cholecystectomy if they have symptomatic gallstones.
    • Address concerns about impaired growth or delayed puberty.
    • Manage leg ulcers appropriately.
    • Refer people with suspected pulmonary hypertension, or worsening symptoms.
    • Manage minor episodes of priapism. It is important to enquire about this issue as the person may be too embarrassed to report it.
    • Manage nocturnal enuresis, which is common because of the production of large quantities of dilute urine.
    • Identify renal problems early, and treat hypertension aggressively.
    • Refer people with sleep apnoea.
    • Advice on measures to prevent (or reduce the risk of) complications.

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage cerebrovascular disease in a person with sickle cell disease?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
People who have had a stroke will be managed in secondary care with regular follow up. Most people will have regular blood transfusions (preferably exchange transfusions) to keep their sickle haemoglobin percentage below 30% indefinitely. This means that people are also monitored for iron overload. All children should have annual transcranial Doppler imaging from 3 years of age.

  • Be alert for new symptoms of cerebrovascular disease.
    • Admit all children and adults for urgent assessment if they present with:
      • A history suggestive of transient ischaemic attacks.
      • A first episode of an acute severe headache, or a significant change in the type of headache, as these may be presenting features of intracranial haemorrhage or venous sinus thrombosis.
    • Refer all children and adults for urgent assessment if they present with:
      • Cognitive abnormalities, as these may be due to silent infarcts. There may be a decline in academic performance, which always justifies investigation.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are largely based on expert opinion in the guidelines Sickle cell disease in childhood: standards and guidelines for clinical care published by the NHS Sickle Cell and Thalassaemia Screening Programme in partnership with the Sickle Cell Society [PHE, 2010] and Standards for the clinical care of adults with sickle cell disease in the UK published by the Sickle Cell Society [Sickle Cell Society, 2008].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage chronic pain in a person with sickle cell disease?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
All types of chronic pain in sickle cell disease require multidisciplinary support, with the general approach being similar to other types of chronic pain. Although the person should be attending regular review by a specialist, most of the management of chronic pain will take place in primary care.

  • Determine the cause of pain, if possible. Common causes include chronic arthritis, avascular necrosis, or vertebral collapse.
  • Consider the need for referral.
    • Refer people with persistent pain to an orthopaedic surgeon for investigations, including magnetic resonance imaging (MRI).
    • Refer people with avascular necrosis for rapid assessment and operation if deemed necessary. The initial management should be conservative, with analgesia, physiotherapy, and partial weight-bearing on crutches.
  • If referral is not indicated, manage pain in primary care.
    • Explain that chronic pain is difficult to eradicate and that the aim is to relieve pain as much as possible.
      • Prescribe regular medium- to long-acting opiates and monitor the person regularly. Prescribe an opiate for breakthrough pain. See the CKS topic on Analgesia - mild-to-moderate pain for prescribing information. 
      • Consider a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID), provided there are no contraindications. Monitor renal function and proteinuria regularly if an NSAID is prescribed. See the CKS topic on NSAIDs - prescribing issues for prescribing information. 
    • Neuropathic pain may also occur in people with sickle cell disease. See the CKS topic on Neuropathic pain - drug treatment for more information. 
    • Psychological therapies (for example relaxation, hypnosis, and cognitive behavioural therapy [CBT]) may be helpful for some people. 
      • CBT will be considered in secondary care for all children who have frequent episodes of pain 
  • Ensure that the person has an annual needs assessment, medication review, and health education.
    • This should be done wherever is most suitable for the person (that is, in primary, secondary, or community care) and should cover: 
      • Pain control and the person's expectations of pain control.
      • Career, vocational, and employment advice.
      • Occupational and/or psychological therapy.
      • Advice on minimizing harm, for example avoiding high-impact exercise or sports (as they can exacerbate damage) and maintaining a healthy weight.
    • Where appropriate, involve family members, friends, and carers.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are largely based on expert opinion in the guidelines Sickle cell disease in childhood: standards and guidelines for clinical care published by the NHS Sickle Cell and Thalassaemia Screening Programme in partnership with the Sickle Cell Society [PHE, 2010] and Standards for the clinical care of adults with sickle cell disease in the UK published by the Sickle Cell Society [Sickle Cell Society, 2008], and in a review article on managing sickle cell disease [Brousse et al, 2014].

Psychological therapies
  • The information on psychological therapies is also based on a Cochrane systematic review (search date: Januray 2014), which found evidence that psychological therapies may help children and adolescents manage pain and its disabling consequences [Eccleston et al, 2014].
    • The evidence showed that both relaxation and cognitive behavioural therapy are effective in reducing the intensity of pain from different causes, including sickle cell disease (2 studies, n = 91), immediately after treatment.

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage chronic sickle lung in a person with sickle cell disease?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Children and adults with chronic sickle lung disease will be managed in secondary care.

  • The primary care physician should:
    • Treat any chest infection early.
    • Give advice on smoking cessation, where necessary. See the CKS topic on Smoking cessation for more information.
    • Ensure vaccinations are up to date. See the section on Immunizations for more information.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on expert opinion in the guidelines Sickle cell disease in childhood: standards and guidelines for clinical care published by the NHS Sickle Cell and Thalassaemia Screening Programme in partnership with the Sickle Cell Society [PHE, 2010] and Standards for the clinical care of adults with sickle cell disease in the UK published by the Sickle Cell Society [Sickle Cell Society, 2008].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage eye problems in a person with sickle cell disease?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
All people with sickle cell disease should be evaluated yearly by an ophthalmologist. Ocular problems are rare before 15 years of age.

  • Refer people immediately if they present with:
    • Acute loss of vision — this may be due to occlusion of the central retinal artery, which should be treated by immediate blood transfusion.
    • Acute change in vision — causes include vitreous haemorrhage and retinal detachment.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: This recommendation is based on expert opinion in the guidelines Sickle cell disease in childhood: standards and guidelines for clinical care published by the NHS Sickle Cell and Thalassaemia Screening Programme in partnership with the Sickle Cell Society [PHE, 2010] and Standards for the clinical care of adults with sickle cell disease in the UK published by the Sickle Cell Society [Sickle Cell Society, 2008], and in a review article on managing sickle cell disease [Claster and Vichinsky, 2003].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage gallstones in a person with sickle cell disease?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Gallstones are very common and ofter cause intermittent abdominal pain.

  • For management information, see the CKS topic on Gallstones.
  • If the gallstones are causing unbearable symptoms, refer the person for consideration of cholecystectomy.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: This recommendation is based on expert opinion in the guidelines Sickle cell disease in childhood: standards and guidelines for clinical care published by the NHS Sickle Cell and Thalassaemia Screening Programme in partnership with the Sickle Cell Society [PHE, 2010] and Standards for the clinical care of adults with sickle cell disease in the UK published by the Sickle Cell Society [Sickle Cell Society, 2008].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage impaired growth in a child or young person with sickle cell disease?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Growth (weight and height) will usually be monitored at least annually in secondary care.

  • Consider:
    • Zinc supplementation if growth is retarded (seek specialist advice).
    • Referral to a paediatric dietitian if the child is hospitalized frequently.
    • Referral to a paediatric endocrinologist if there are no physical signs of puberty by 14 years of age in a girl, and by 14 years 6 months of age in a boy.
  • Reassure children with delayed growth and delayed puberty (and/or their parents/carers) that they will reach a normal adult height.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are largely based on recommendations in the guideline Sickle cell disease in childhood: standards and guidelines for clinical care published by the NHS Sickle Cell and Thalassaemia Screening Programme in partnership with the Sickle Cell Society [PHE, 2010].

Considering zinc supplementation
  • The guideline development group (GDG) of the joint guideline identified evidence from a randomized controlled trial (RCT) which showed some improvement in height and weight after supplementation with zinc sulphate. Another controlled trial showed a reduction in infections and hospital admissions in children taking zinc supplements [PHE, 2010]. Based on these, the GDG concluded that zinc supplementation should be considered if growth is retarded. 
  • A Cochrane systematic review (search date: February 2013) assessed the effect of zinc supplementation in the treatment of thalassaemia and sickle cell disease [Swe et al, 2013].
    • There was no evidence from RCTs to indicate any benefit of zinc supplementation with regards to serum zinc level in people with thalassaemia. However, height velocity was noted to increase among those who received zinc supplements.
Delay in puberty
  • Expert opinion in the joint guideline is that puberty may be delayed by 2–3 years in children with sickle cell disease, and by 6 months in children with Hb SC sickle cell disorder. However, delayed skeletal maturation during adolescence allows for a longer growth period in the long bones; therefore, children and their parents can be reassured that the child will attain a normal adult height [PHE, 2010].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage leg ulcers in a person with sickle cell disease?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Leg ulcers will often be managed in secondary care by a multidisciplinary team, according to local guidelines. 

  • The primary healthcare professional should:
    • Prescribe adequate pain relief. See the CKS topic on Analgesia - mild-to-moderate pain for more information on pain relief.
    • Suspect underlying osteomyelitis if the person has:
      • Fever.
      • Bone tenderness.
      • A high leukocyte count.
      • A high C-reactive protein level.
    • Seek specialist advice if the ulcer fails to respond to conservative measures.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are largely based on expert opinion in the guidelines Sickle cell disease in childhood: standards and guidelines for clinical care published by the NHS Sickle Cell and Thalassaemia Screening Programme in partnership with the Sickle Cell Society [PHE, 2010] and Standards for the clinical care of adults with sickle cell disease in the UK published by the Sickle Cell Society [Sickle Cell Society, 2008].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage episodes of priapism in a person with sickle cell disease?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Priapism is common and can be an acute or chronic complication of sickle cell disease. It is important to enquire about this issue as the person may be too embarrassed to report it.

  • Minor episodes of priapism may be treated in primary care provided that the episodes:
    • Are isolated or infrequent.
    • Last less than 3 hours.
  • Advise the following to help abort an attack:
    • Bladder emptying before sleep.
    • Jogging.
    • Warm baths.
    • Analgesia.
  • Advise the man that if priapism persists, he should attend hospital and allow enough time so that emergency hospital treatment can be started within 3 hours.
  • Refer men with stuttering priapism (frequent minor attacks several times a week) to a specialist, as oral etilefrine may be beneficial.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are largely based on expert opinion in the guidelines Sickle cell disease in childhood: standards and guidelines for clinical care published by the NHS Sickle Cell and Thalassaemia Screening Programme in partnership with the Sickle Cell Society [PHE, 2010] and Standards for the clinical care of adults with sickle cell disease in the UK published by the Sickle Cell Society [Sickle Cell Society, 2008].

Priapism as a medical emergency
  • The time that is required to elapse before priapism is considered to be a medical emergency differs slightly between guideline groups:
    • Expert opinion in the guideline Sickle cell disease in childhood: standards and guidelines for clinical care is that acute priapism becomes an emergency after 3 hours [PHE, 2010].
    • Expert opinion in the guideline Standards for the clinical care of adults with sickle cell disease in the UK is that acute priapism becomes an emergency after 4 hours [Sickle Cell Society, 2008].
  • Due to the risk of cavernosal fibrosis and impotence, which are serious and potentially permanent consequences of prolonged, untreated priapism, CKS recommends that the shorter time of 3 hours should be considered a medical emergency.

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage nocturnal enuresis in a child with sickle cell disease?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Nocturnal enuresis will often be managed in secondary care. However, the primary care clinician will need to provide supportive care and advice.

  • Explain to the child and/or the parents/carers that enuresis is common in people with sickle cell disease, because they produce large quantities of dilute urine.
  • Give general advice on the management of enuresis. See the CKS topic on Bedwetting (enuresis) for more information.
    • Be aware that children with sickle cell disease tend not to respond to behavioural management techniques, such as star charts and mattress alarms.
  • Consider treatment with oral or nasal desmopressin, particularly for school trips or sleepovers.
  • Refer children:
    • To an ear, nose, and throat specialist if the history is suggestive of obstructive sleep apnoea, as hypoxia may exacerbate nocturnal enuresis.
    • A specialist enuresis clinic if the child is still enuretic by 7 years of age.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on expert opinion in the guideline Sickle cell disease in childhood: standards and guidelines for clinical care published by the NHS Sickle Cell and Thalassaemia Screening Programme in partnership with the Sickle Cell Society [PHE, 2010] and in a British Medical Journal (BMJ) review article on sickle cell anaemia [Brousse et al, 2014].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage pulmonary hypertension in a person with sickle cell disease?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
People with pulmonary hypertension will be managed in secondary care. Pulmonary hypertension is often asymptomatic (even when severe). Adults with sickle cell disease should be screened every 1–2 years using transthoracic echocardiography; children will be screened if they have chronic sickle lung or unexplained hypoxia.

  • Refer children and adults urgently if they develop symptoms of pulmonary hypertension, including:
    • Worsening hypoxia.
    • Chest pain.
    • Increasing breathlessness.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: This recommendation is based on expert opinion in the guidelines Sickle cell disease in childhood: standards and guidelines for clinical care published by the NHS Sickle Cell and Thalassaemia Screening Programme in partnership with the Sickle Cell Society [PHE, 2010] and Standards for the clinical care of adults with sickle cell disease in the UK published by the Sickle Cell Society [Sickle Cell Society, 2008], and on expert opinion in a review article on managing sickle cell disease [Claster and Vichinsky, 2003].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage renal disease and hypertension in a person with sickle cell disease?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Blood pressure, urea and electrolytes, and dipstick testing of the urine for protein will be done annually from childhood in secondary care. Primary care clinicians will be involved in monitoring for hypertension and chronic kidney disease (CKD).

  • Aim for a target blood pressure of:
    • 130/80 mmHg in people who have proteinuria.
    • 140/90 mmHg in people with no proteinuria.
  • Advise a good fluid intake to prevent dehydration, as people with sickle cell disease produce large quantities of dilute urine.
  • Be aware that renal function may deteriorate rapidly in people with sickle cell disease.
    • Refer the following to a renal physician for further investigations:
      • All people with new hypertension or newly increased urea or creatinine levels.
      • All people with new proteinuria (quantified by measuring an albumin–creatinine ratio, a protein–creatinine ratio, or the amount of protein in a 24-hour urine collection), as this may be associated with a rapid decline in renal function. Treatment with an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor or an angiotensin-II receptor antagonist is protective.
  • Refer children and adults with haematuria.
  • Refer children and adults urgently if they present with symptoms suggestive of renal medullary cancer — haematuria, weight loss, loin pain, fever, and abdominal pain.
    • Refer using the suspected cancer pathway referral (for an appointment within 2 weeks).

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Blood pressure and renal monitoring

  • These recommendations are based on expert opinion in the guidelines Sickle cell disease in childhood: standards and guidelines for clinical care published by the NHS Sickle Cell and Thalassaemia Screening Programme in partnership with the Sickle Cell Society [PHE, 2010] and Standards for the clinical care of adults with sickle cell disease in the UK published by the Sickle Cell Society [Sickle Cell Society, 2008].

Haematuria
  • The recommendation that all people with haematuria should be investigated is based on expert opinion in a review article on managing sickle cell disease, which states that in people with sickle cell disease, haematuria may occur secondary to papillary necrosis or, very rarely, be due to renal medullary carcinoma [Claster and Vichinsky, 2003].
  • The clinical features of renal medullary cancer are based on expert opinion in the Standards for the clinical care of adults with sickle cell disease in the UK [Sickle Cell Society, 2008].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage sleep apnoea in a person with sickle cell disease?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Sleep apnoea is common in children and adults with sickle cell disease and may be due to tonsillar hypertrophy or other causes of sleep disordered breathing.  

  • Refer children and adults with a history suggestive of sleep apnoea for sleep studies.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: This recommendation is based on expert opinion in the guideline Standards for the clinical care of adults with sickle cell disease in the UK published by the Sickle Cell Society [Sickle Cell Society, 2008], which states that it is important to diagnose and treat any underlying cause of sleep apnoea, as hypoxia can lead to an increase in the number of acute painful episodes and strokes.
